segments.text: No more calls because they had, the water was winding down at that period of time.
Okay.
And then I graduated and the elder had called me and said there was a veteran that died at Brennan and he might want to come over and look and I did and so I bought his practice you might say.
All right, now how did you meet this young lady?
Well, do I have to admit that?
You want me to tell us?
Well, it doesn't make any difference.
I met him when we were double dating.
Go ahead.
Anyhow, yeah, we had to update it, and then I asked her for a date, and they went from there.
Okay, and had you gotten married before you graduated?
No.
Oh, okay.
It was almost a year before we went over there and then we got married.
So you go to Brenham and open up a veterinary practice in?
In Brenham, Texas.
In what year?
1945, February.
February 45.
And it was a general practice?
General practice, yeah.
There's nothing like it was then.

Those were, in that time there was, during the war there were very few tractors made, and a lot of things weren't there, but horse and mules were still holding on, and a lot of it was horse and mule, and a few small animals.
And it was a challenge, but I guess because of the variety it was easier.
Can you give some examples of what the veterinarian's fee was at that time?
What did you charge?
Well, trying to figure that out, I was accused of being too cheap.
It was a dollar a mile plus five dollars to deliver a calf.
would vaccinate a dog for two and a half.
And basically that was it.
I remember I did an interception for, I rejected the gut of a cow that had an interception and that was $25.
And that was foolish on my part, but not having a mentor, and you may recognize that
I'm very strong on the influence of mentors, and I did not have one, and going out and working on those things.
Fees were very inexpensive, $5.
How many other veterinarians were there then in Washington County?
There was one other at that time.
He was a non-graduate, a graduate of Fort Worth Veterinary School.
and about 1900.
And later there, others came, and I think there's 10 or 12 over there now in the same unit.
How long did you practice over there before you joined, came back and joined the faculty?
I was over there about four and a half years.
Okay.
And I had an opportunity to, I decided, I really wasn't, it wasn't what I wanted because
I like to do something, I want to do it reasonably well.
And so I left there and went to, took a job at LSU in the Experiment Station and with the Veterinary Science Department.
And there I taught, did research in poultry diseases and other animal diseases.
And then the opportunity came to the Air Force was, put a pretty good pressure on
upon us and so I volunteered and was commissioned captain.
This would be during the Korean War period?
During the Korean War period in 1951.
And where did you, where were you sent?
I went to Edwards Air Force Base, the Air Force flight center, Chuck Yeager's whole place.
And he was there doing, flying the X-4 at that time.
We lived on the base.
What were your professional duties?
Well, we were, at that time, they had a chip colony there and I had little exposure to that.
And they were using those to study wind blasts.
And Colonel Stapp had a program where he had these sleds lined up on the tracks and they would use rocket power.
At that time they were developing rockets.
rocket-powered planes and rocket-powered this, and they used that to propel these sleds with these chimps at high speeds down these tracks.
And then the main assignment there was food service inspections and sanitation, sanitary.
I guess like public health officers do.
And then we, for the quartermaster market center in Los Angeles, would buy meat and mainly eggs and poultry.
At one time I had five master sergeants in my outfit and two others.
And I really didn't have a lot of work to do.
Did you find that a pleasant assignment?
And you were there how long?
We were there two years, and we signed up for three.
And like everything else, that was winding down, and they came out and said, you can go if you like.
And I said, I like.
But it was very nice.
We lived out there in the hospital compound with a lot of good people in the same boat we were in, and physicians that had been through the same
kind of a situation.
Where after that?

Well, I had committed when I was at LSU to go to the LSU Medical School to study virology, and because of this other thing intervened, I came back, I said, well, I still am interested in microbiology, and so we came back, I went over to Texas University, and I went, they sent me over and said, well,
I went to see Dr. Williams who then was head of the Department of Microbiology and also the head of their athletic committee.
But anyhow, he said, he said, go over to graduate school.
I went over there and I walked in and there was a little gal sitting at the table there and I told her what I wanted to do and she said, have you got two years of foreign languages?
I said, no, I got one.
She said, well, you can't do that.
That's what's the matter.
All you dentists and all you other people, you
you think you can get away with this, and I went and got out of there and I came over here.
Well, the only program they offered here was a Ph.D. in the medical area was in pathology, and so I talked to Hilton Smith, and he said, well, go over and set it up.
Now, what role, what was his task?
He was the head of the department.
All right.
And what's his first name?
Hilton Atwell Smith.
Oh, Hilton Smith.
Okay.
Yeah.
And so this is 1953?
Two?
Three.
Three.
Yeah.
How many other doctoral students were there?
One.
Ph.D.
Okay.
And I was the second one to get a degree, a Ph.D. that takes you to finish curriculum.
How long did it take?
It didn't take a heck of a long time.
I started in 53, I got a master's in 54, and I got a PSD in January, I guess, of 57.
Was the GI Bill important to you?
Some, yeah.
I had saved quite a bit of money by cashing in my leave time from the service.
We borrowed a little money.
Where did you all live?
We lived first on College Main.
A little house up there.
It's now apartments there, huh?
Yeah.
Chemistry teacher.
The kooky one.
Oh, yeah, sure.
Yeah, yeah.
That's right.
Who was your chairman of your doctoral?
Hilton Smith.
Hilton Smith.
All right.
He was quite a, he wrote probably the very best yet, and the very first literary pathology text.
At that time, was he probably the most highly respected member of the department?
Well, he was the member of the department.
And the others were assistants.
Oh, okay.
And I mean by that, he was the leader in his, in veterinary pathology.
About how big was the veterinary faculty then in numbers?
Oh, veterinary faculty?
The total.
I guess there were 30, 40.
And four in pathology, did you say?
And still located where it had been.
Yes, it was down in the old building down there.
I remember that it was, I did a lot of study at night.
And the reason I did that, that Hilton was a very capable person.
And he told the university that he had to have air condition because his paraffin wasn't,
would melt so he got a wind air conditioner and that was in the old hospital.
Who was the dean when you were a doctoral student?
B-O-U-G-H-T-O-N. That's a very interesting history.
That's pretty well out loud.
I just pulled out that book there that Pat Byrne wrote on history.
He replaced, at that time, Dr. Dunn, who was the head of pathology, microbiology, and all that.
Belton was a
A researcher from, had been out in West Texas, done a lot of work and research and the administration wanted to bring somebody in to develop the program.
And they brought him in and he picked, he decided he needed a pathologist, so he knew Hilton Smith.
And so he brought him in.
And I was fortunate enough just to happen in and find, well, this is a program.
As you look back on your doctoral studies, what were the most important courses, most important research that you did?
Well, as a student, I was quite interested in renal quality or kidney diseases.
I did some work on, it was Hilton's idea.
He said, I can't diagnose leptospirosis.
I know that's what it is, but I can't prove it.
I want to know why.

So my dissertation was to find out what parameters influence the persistence and the capability of demonstrating those and then he arranged for me to go to the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington.
And they were working on that spiral scenario, so I continued that as a resident there, and then came back and wrote my dissertation.
Now, how many other doctoral students were there when you were working on yours?
Just one.
Just one?
So there are two?
S-I-P-P-E-L, so that there was not a group to gather with and be friends with or anything like that?
Not really.
And Hilton was a rather unique person.
He had some of my own philosophy, I guess, that he would say, what about this?
And I'd expect him to explain it to me.
He said, you figure it out.
He said, we'll discuss it.
Did you become acquainted with some of the faculty members that became an important friendship later while you were a student?
Well, there weren't many around.
Millet, honey.
Huh?
He was a faculty member.
Did you make acquaintance with some of those faculty members?
Yeah.
I studied under John Miller.
Describe him as a teacher.
He was a gentleman's gentleman, an excellent teacher, very concerned about his students.
And being a gentleman without children of his own,
I can say he had a certain respect for them and treated them as such.
Did you all have a nickname for him?
No, Dr. John.
Dr. John.
Other faculty members that you met as a student that you remember gratefully, proudly?
Of course, I appreciate Hilton Smith.
Hilton was a very intelligent person, but he was standoffish.
But I still respect a person, a professional that named himself in a professional way.
And of course, there was Dr. A.
Square Leonard.
A.
Square?
Yeah, A.
A. Leonard.
That's what the students called him, A.
Square.
And he was head of the clinics and what have you.
And some of them, we had a lot of others, R.D.
Turk.
Did he have a nickname?
Not really that I know of.
Everybody called him, his colleagues called him Dick.
But they told a lot of stories about Dr. Turk.
He was hard of hearing and wore a hearing aid.
You heard this probably.
He would be lecturing and back there and somebody would say something derogatory in the back room and he'd just say, you know, I can't hear you but I can read your lips.
He, on the day in 64 when I got this teaching award, he got the next one.
And I was up on the stage and when he walked by the microphone, he said loudly to Mr.
Rudder, Earl, y'all must have been pretty damn hard up to give me one of these.
And Mr.
Rudder was kind of like.
That's the way he is.
He was.
Was he always congenial with everybody?
Oh, yeah.
And he talked.
He was a very intelligent person.
And if you live long enough, you'll know that certain things push certain people into certain endeavors.
And I think his hearing pushed him into academia.
Okay.
And he was a Kansas State graduate.
Very intelligent.
But he was always
he could talk a lot, and one time he was talking to me, and I responded, I didn't know what to say.
He said, you've just been bamboozled.
Now, as a young couple, what community activities did you all get involved in while you were a graduate student?
Studying in church.
Which church?
Lutheran.
Lutheran.
And it then was located where?
Right where it was.

Right now, except where the main church was, where the fellowship hall is where the church was, it was an old house that they had converted and made into it, and then later on the new church was built.
They actually took over.
Well, it was a mission church for students.
Now, Missouri Synod or American Lutheran?
About how big was the congregation in those days?
A hundred?
Less.
I think less than that.
I really do.
But you had a full-time minister.
Well, they always did.
We weren't here when it was first organized.
But Swaggart was there, wasn't it?
Yeah.
And yeah, he was full-time.
And where did a young graduate student and his family go if they were going to have any kind of enjoyment on a Saturday night?
Brown.
Huh, where?
Brown.
Oh, to go to family, okay.
Either that or we didn't do a whole lot past school
You know, he was so involved, he was so tied up with his research that we didn't.
And I had the children a whole lot.
Of course, I participated in a few.
I think the graduate student wives had just a few little get-togethers.
And you didn't have a huge amount of money.
Yeah.
Because I wasn't working.
I was home with two children.
All right, as you are getting near the end of this doctoral program,
What did you think you were going to do professionally?
Well, I was going into research, education and research, and I had an appointment to, well, I was at that time, I guess what I, I was dickering with Oklahoma State, the department head there.
And they, I was in Washington, D.C., and Hilton at that time was on the advisory board for me.
at the institute.
And he had had a resignation, and so he called me and asked me if I was interested.
And he told me what salary I wanted.
I said, well, the salaries are not that intriguing, but the opportunities are.
Now, to join the faculty here?
Yeah.
And this is 1953?
Do you remember what the salary?
About $4,500.
And so you decided to accept?
Oh, yes.
In fact, we had signed the one for Oklahoma State.
We were ready to mail it in when he called him and offered that to him.
I had an opportunity.
I'd dickered with the Air Force office in Washington.
about going back into the Air Force service.
And they told me, they said, you can go to Alaska if you like for your foreign duty, which you'd have to do now.
And so we talked against that, I guess, and fought against it.
Describe the department in terms of its people.
and its facilities when you became a faculty member in 1954?
Well, we were down in the building, down in the civil engineering building on the second floor.
Hilton had his office in one building and it was a room that had a place for a secretary and a lab.
and we were assigned various offices down.
You'd get one here and one there and I had an office down there and that was pretty much it.
There was only about four of us.
Only one lab?
One lab.
But did each of you have a workspace in that lab?
We had a place where we had, those were rather large rooms, and we had to have a table where we could store some of our specimens, stuff like that.
But all of the lab work, which was then, was pretty much cut and dried paraffin and embedded pathology tissues.
And that was about it, yeah.
And for faculty?
I believe that was about it.
later what I took over was five.
Hilton resigned.
Alright and what were your duties when you began?
What courses, what assignments?
I helped, worked in the laboratory, teaching laboratory of the histopathology part of Hilton's course and then full of necropsy duty which is servicing the
the animals that came from a clinic.
And Hilda did most of the histopathology then, the biopsies and stuff that they wanted tumor.
That was his business, he took care of that.
At that time we had no research at the time, but later they did develop.
Which, in which courses in the veterinary curriculum did Joel
Did you all have some for all three years?
There was one basic course in veterinary pathology, then later they developed a course in clinical pathology, and then there was a duty with the clinic later on that was developed.
And about how many students were in each veterinary class then that was admitted?
Basically 64.
All male, all Texans?
All male and mostly all Texans, but I don't remember.
The next day I signed a contract with the state of Louisiana to accept nine students from
Normally were those nine students good students?
They were good students because they were selected mostly from the applicants from LSU that took the pre-vet, and they knew that that pre-vet program was there.
They were mostly good students, yes.
Describe some of your early teaching experiences with
What were some of the things that you soon learned you were going to encounter?
What were the students like as they began their coursework?
Well, basically the department was pretty stark, and the students were
fairly quiet.
They responded accordingly.
And I don't know of any particular exciting times that were at that.
Did they think of pathology as a hard course or easy?
I figured it was one of the harder courses.
And they'd take it the first year?
It was the fourth year.
And your...
The year preceded graduation.
Okay.
Describe a typical day for you as a young faculty member.
What time did you get there?
What did you do?
What time did you come home?
Well, we were there at 8 o'clock.
And you know, it was five days, six days a week.
And we were out at 8 and...
we'd have a class, there'd be a lecture in which we would attend, Ronald Hilton would lecture and then we would go into the labs, which here we used the two sections twice a week.
And we would prepare that and go in there and the students would all have a microscope and they would, we would circulate among them and they'd have to answer their questions.
And then we'd ask them questions and set up practical exams and things like that.
And that was over whether it was back to work or research or whatever we were doing.
What time would you normally come home?
I don't know what time.
It was usually home for dinner and then back to level.
So you came home for lunch midday and then...
Went back.
Went back.
And then came home say maybe about 6 to eat.
Okay.
Then went back and didn't come home until about 11.
It was interesting enough to... And we felt that's what we should be doing.
Did you feel well accepted as a junior faculty member by your colleagues?
Yes, I think so.
I think that there was that peer, not peer, but that relationship of the senior professor and the junior professor.
I could see that, but it didn't bother me because I've been brought up in a discipline
world all my life.
Did the students soon develop a nickname for you?
I'm not sure.
My son got, my son got a time to borrow some notes.
He graduated from that, from one of the students.
His classmates, in that, he found in the back of it, he says, what's that, Bridget?
He'll get your A.
At that time, what do you think was the reputation of the School of Veterinary Medicine here nationally?
How did we...
I think it was respected, but I think it was also downgraded because it was a school of the South, and that thing which hangs over anything in the South is not good as it is in the East.
And the only vet school anywhere near was Oklahoma State?
Oklahoma State, I think, was developed in the 50s or so.
I was on faculty here before they were developed.
Oh, so it wasn't, okay.
No, it didn't exist.
So Kenton State had one?
Kenton State was an old school.
Okay.
And Cornell.
But there wasn't one to go all the way to...
Even Georgia was a bloke in the 50s.
Okay.
Auburn had one.
Yeah.
Auburn had one, and I don't remember the dates of those.
I've never been bothered by those things.
That was one of the problems I had in classes, that if there were eponyms, I refused to learn them.
I know that about one flunked me on my pre-lab because I didn't know what Ben Ness's walker disease was.
I said, yeah, sure, I'll tell you all about it.
